title: Facial Fracture Treatment
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: Call 911 if:
bullets: The person has difficulty breathing.
The upper and lower jaws don't meet properly.
There is an open wound with exposed bone.
The person has blurred or double vision or trouble moving their eyeballs.

items: The person has difficulty breathing.

There is an open wound with exposed bone.
The person has blurred or double vision or trouble moving their eyeballs.

sections.heading: 1. Get Medical Help Immediately
content: You need to see a health care provider for a facial fracture, including a broken nose, jaw, cheekbone, or eye socket.

content_blocks.text: You need to see a health care provider for a facial fracture, including a broken nose, jaw, cheekbone, or eye socket.

sections.heading: 2. Control Pain and Swelling
bullets: Keep the person's face elevated to allow blood to drain.
Apply ice for swelling.

items: Keep the person's face elevated to allow blood to drain.
Apply ice for swelling.

sections.heading: 3. Follow Up
bullets: The health care provider will examine the person's face and may order X-rays or other imaging tests, including a CT scan.
The health care provider may immobilize broken bones to help them heal.
Medications may be prescribed to relieve pain and inflammation and prevent infection.
Surgery may be needed.
